Posts.Content: Lol that's so funny Emma. I'm reasonably new to this game. I had my new 'foob' fitted last week and l absolutely love it! It's the Amoena Natura and can honestly say it's a gazillion times better than my softie (although that did serve me well in the early days). My boobs both hang properly in my bra now which makes me feel alot more confident.  My breast nurse asked me to keep the box just incase it were to split within the next 2 years. That way they'd be able to return it for a new one. I asked her about having a spare incase there was a problem and she said to come back to her for another if I feel the need after I've finished my chemo. Cathy x
Posts.Title: There's a hole in my prosthesis, dear Liza, dear Liza...

Posts.Content: Good evening Might seem like a dumb question but something's bugging me.......Is there a difference between TAC and TAX chemo? My oncologist is putting me on 6 cycles of TAC ( Docetaxel,  Doxorubicin & Cyclophosphamide).  Thanks Cathy
Posts.Title: Another TAC Question

Posts.Content: Thanks Jelly, I thought that was the case. Most people here appear to be on Fec & Tax. I must be special lol. I've been following your excellent blog since 'all this' started and I've just invested in the Jelly Pong Pong Wide Awake make-up after your recommendation.  It looks fab! Just need to learn how to apply it now and as I have a full set of eyebrows, i'll just have to jolly well wait!  Cathy x
Posts.Title: Another TAC Question

Posts.Content: Hey Coot I totally feel for you. It's a pretty grim time right now but you'll soon be back in the drivers seat and look back on this awful time and think....really? Did I actually go through all that? My survivor friends (and I have quite a few) often tell me that and I can't wait to be the one spreading my wise words of wisdom in the near future! I had my first TAC yesterday and feeling a little wiped but steroids are keeping me in check. I've fasted since Weds and had no sickness and been pottering about a bit today and generally feel myself - early days I know but am definitely digging this fasting lark. As long as you're not diabetic or underweight, it might be worth thinking about that for the next one. As part of my control freakism, I always like to have a few tricks up my sleeve lol. All the best my lovely  Cathy x
Posts.Title: 1st fec

Posts.Content: Hi Mandie Glad you're feeling a bit better today. I too have to have the injections - 7 days worth after each cycle. I managed to administer it myself today with the district nurse watching over -  felt quite pleased with myself. My only problem now is big bone ache and i'm lying here with pillows and a hot water bottle trying to ease the ache. So far everything reminds me of pregnancy including that strange toothbrush/toothpaste thing that only ever made me gag when I was expecting - weird!  As regards to shaving, I was going to attempt it today but kind of chickened out at the last minute. I just want to get it over with but it feels like such a huge thing. The kiddies want to get involved so I'm going to let my daughter do me a funky fringe with shaved sides and the boys want to attempt some tram lines (god forbid). And besides, it gives them something to talk about in Show n' Tell at school lol.  Have fun with the wig fitting tomorrow! Gotta say, I love mine!  Cathy x
Posts.Title: 1st fec

Posts.Content: Good morning Just interested to hear if anybody has had any experience with fasting before and after chemo? I've been reading lots about it on the American site and there seem to be alot of positive outcome from it - they've even started trials on this.  The general idea is to fast 60 hours before and 24 hours after and of course drink plenty of fluids. This then is supposed to  make the chemo work better and lessen the side effects considerably. What do think? Am I clutching at straws? I'll try anything!!!!  Cathy x
Posts.Title: Fasting Before & After Chemo

Posts.Content: Thank you ladies! Fasting it is then! I certainly think 84hrs is slightly excessive and quite frankly I love my food far too much so I shan't be going down that road lol. But yes, sensible fasting sounds totally do-able and anything for an easier time of it and besides, I have a fair amount of meat on me so I don't think I'll be wasting away too quickly.  Thanks again, you've been very helpful. Cathy x
Posts.Title: Fasting Before & After Chemo

Posts.Content: Hi there everyone I've been to see my oncologist this morning and everything seems pretty straight foward, h owever he has decided to put me through 6 x TAC!!! Call me old fashioned but I was expecting 3x FEC & TAX. Apparantly my age (38) has a part to play in this but I really wasn't expecting 6 sessions of the (so called) really hard stuff.     Any advice would be greatly received.   Cathy x
Posts.Title: TAC Question......

Posts.Content: Chances are everything will be fine - they usually are. Unfortunately for me, I had to rely on my gut instinct. As i was only 38, no bc in my family and breast fed my 3 children for a year each,  they had ruled cancer out - infact, fibrocystic breasts was their exact diagnosis. I pushed for a biopsy whilst having an ultra-sound and by doing so, I saved my own life that day. The medical team have been fantastic on my journey so far - i'm not knocking them , it just shows that being in tune with your own body can really pay off in these situations.  All the best, I'm sure everything will be fine. Cathy x
Posts.Title: Second opinion - lump?

Posts.Content: Hi Coot, I too have had a bad cough and cold with no raised temperature. I'm having my bloods done in the morning in the hope of having my 3rd TAC on Thursday. Gotta say, the tax leaves me pretty achey for about 7/8 days and very tired but no sickness (just tax trots.....ummm nice). As I'm having 6 sessions of tax, I've been informed that each one gets that bit harder so I'm mentally prepared for that. The big positive is I had my 39th birthday yesterday so managed to bag a lovely meal with my family and friends and could actually taste it!  If I get the thumbs up for Thurs, I'll get a lovely Christmas dinner in too! Yes, for me one of the best parts is when those long awaited taste buds re-appear.     Fingers crossed for tomorrows bloods - I'm sure you'll be fine.     Cathy xxx
Posts.Title: what delays chemo?

Posts.Content: Hi Coot, I live in Cheltenham but my sis lives in Devon (not much use).  You're right though, it's incredibly reassuring knowing somebody is having the same the op on the same day.  As regards to your question about bras.......I recently purchased the Genie Bra from Amazon. I've got to say, they are fantastically comfortable and have a little pocket on the inside for your softie etc. They came in a pack of 3 for (roughly) £24.99 and are also available in pink to support BC. Definitely worth a look.    All the best Cathy x
Posts.Title: impending masectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Coot After many weeks of snooping around on this forum, i finally decided to show myself! I was diagnosed back in early July and after what seems a lifetime ago I've finally got a 2nd date for my MX and SNB (first time i got as far as the anesthetic room only to be told my temperature was too high for surgery....grrrrr). Anyway, Im all set for Wednesday too! So wishing us both and anybody else lots of luck.  Must also say how wonderful and inspiring you all are. You've all put me at ease in one or another and I find this forum a HUGE sanity saver. Thanks ladies. I'll keep y'all posted.  Eggshell
Posts.Title: impending masectomy

Posts.Content: Lol! I can't tell you how relieved I am to hear it's not me going crazy. What a strange side effect? I do agree with you Strong Willed, there's certainly less insulation since my d cup went.  Thanks for the replies   Cathy x
Posts.Title: A bit of a weird one.....

Posts.Content: Hi all, Im quite new to the forum (although i've been snooping for a many weeks). Just wondered if any of you ladies have experienced only what can be described as a bizzare feeling. I had a right mx last weds and everything seems to be healing well ( slight swelling - nothing major). The thing is, everytime I drink anything cold I have this strange sensation that the liquid is running out of my chest. No pain accompanies it - just a weird feeling. Is it me being odd? Nothing new there lol. You're all fabulous btw. Not sure how I would of got this far without you. Cathy x
Posts.Title: A bit of a weird one.....
